metadata.title: AMD Zodiac
aws::graph::propositions: # Wing-Related Incidents Involving AMD Zodiac CH 601 XL Aircraft
The Dutch government grounded 12 Dutch-registered CH 601 XLs on 24 October 2008.
The Dutch government banned the CH 601 XLs from flying pending an investigation into their structural strength.
The Dutch government's action followed the crash of a European variant of the CH 601 XL design.
The European variant of the CH 601 XL was Rotax powered.
The European variant of the CH 601 XL had 450 kg (992 lb) maximum take-off weight.
The crash of the European variant of the CH 601 XL killed two people.
According to the Dutch government, since 2005, at least seven accidents with Zenith CH601 XLs have happened.
In these seven accidents, one or both wings of the Zenith CH601 XLs failed.
Zenair Europe concluded that none of the accidents are due to a design defect.
Zenair Europe rejected suggestions that the aircraft in the Dutch accident experienced a structural failure.
Zenair Europe's rejection came after a first-hand review of the wreckage.
On 14 April 2009, the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) wrote an urgent letter to the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA).
The NTSB recommended that the FAA ground all Zodiac CH 601 XLs.
The NTSB stated that aerodynamic flutter appears to be the likely source of four U.S. incidents.

text:
#### Wing-related incidents
In the Netherlands, the Dutch government grounded the 12 Dutch-registered CH 601 XLs on 24 October 2008. The planes were banned from flying pending an investigation into their structural strength, following the crash of a European variant of the design (Rotax powered and 450 kg (992 lb) maximum take-off weight) that killed two people. According to the Dutch government, since 2005, "at least seven accidents with Zenith CH601 XLs have happened in which one or both wings have failed". Zenair Europe investigated these accidents, concluded that none are due to a design defect and, after a first-hand review of the wreckage, also rejected suggestions that the aircraft in the Dutch accident experienced a structural failure.

On 14 April 2009, the NTSB wrote an urgent letter to the FAA recommending that they ground all Zodiac CH 601 XLs, saying, "It appears that aerodynamic flutter is the likely source of four of the U.S.
